name: NPR
text:
California State University is requiring all students to take an ethnic studies or social justice course in order to graduate.

But some faculty oppose the broad measure because it does not ensure students take an actual ethnic studies course. 
https://t.co/7QO8twLqIv

name: NPR
text:
A Pittsburgh company won a lucrative federal contract to build a COVID-19 database and gather reams of COVID-19 data instead of the CDC. 

But the contract process was filled with irregularities, NPR found.
https://t.co/UeX4JguJzS

name: NPR
text: In an open letter, a coalition of doctors, health experts and teachers are calling on officials to step back from the push to reopen the economy, saying leaders need to "shut it down, start over" and "do it right."  https://t.co/xWqQXh1ddf

name: NPR
text:
A number of people arrested at Portland protests say the terms of their release prevent them from attending protests going forward — a stipulation First Amendment experts have called cause for concern.
https://t.co/rXygHvH7nC

name: NPR
text: Critics charge the new postmaster general, who is a major donor to President Trump, intends to make the Postal Service "more of a business than a service" — which includes delaying mail delivery and eliminating overtime.  https://t.co/2rujy9bC4e

name: NPR
text:
The power of moms as activists is being proven again by the Wall of Moms protesting in Portland.

Stereotypes about gender, as well as race, have long played a role in shaping that power — as well as who gets to wield it. https://t.co/dNCTRK61kj

name: NPR
text:
Many Asian Americans have joined in demonstrations against systemic racism and police brutality. 

Some are protesting for the first time ever. Others are confronting their own anti-Blackness and that within their communities.
https://t.co/qNVoPG6ayj

name: NPR
text:
The music of @manmanbandband could maybe be best described as "controlled chaos."  

Frontperson Ryan Kattner talks about releasing the new album during a pandemic, plus how the sounds of a guillotine made the final cut.  https://t.co/jzuRbF4sRs

name: NPR
text: The performance style and traditions of both African American gospel and Hebridean psalm singing are explored and celebrated with the Gaelic psalm singers and the Mt. Zion CPCA Church Gospel Choir.  https://t.co/OvIC2sRqaM

name: NPR
text:
Suburban women have been a particular focus of the GOP in the last 20 years, dubbed everything from "soccer moms" to "security moms."

But whatever you call them, they aren't in Trump's corner — and the consequences have been significant for Republicans.
https://t.co/F63mIWw25y

name: NPR
text: In recent days, officials from more than two dozen states have warned residents about unsolicited packages of seeds that appear to be coming from China. They say not to use the seeds, which could produce invasive plants. @wamu885 https://t.co/SjdxJmUPVp

name: NPR
text:
Cape sundews are carnivorous plants that exude sweet, shimmering droplets from their tentacles to lure in unsuspecting insects. 

Once their prey is hopelessly stuck, they wrap it up and dissolve it for a tasty meal. (@KQEDScience) https://t.co/97G603CjXU

name: NPR
text:
NEW: The coronavirus pandemic triggered the sharpest economic contraction in modern American history — as GDP shrank at an annual rate of 32.9% in the second quarter.

"Horrific," one economist says. "We've never seen anything quite like it."
https://t.co/qUaR9tzTcp

name: NPR
text:
For the first time, Amazon acknowledged that it may be misusing data to edge out independent sellers on its site.

Here are 4 key takeaways from yesterday's hearing with Big Tech CEOs.
https://t.co/4wtzAfakQs

name: NPR
text:
In a falsehood-ridden tweet, President Trump suggested delaying the November election.
 
Election Day has been set… https://t.co/V6XCfE7l0S

name: NPR
text:
As to Trump’s specific claims: While almost all states are expanding vote by mail as a result of the pandemic, there is no nationwide turn to universal mail-in voting.

As much as half of the electorate is still expected to cast ballots in person. (2/3)
https://t.co/XkNX8UuFlD

name: NPR
text:
While the president draws a distinction between mail-in and absentee voting, there is essentially no difference.

Trump and many members of his Cabinet and staff have cast votes by mail. (3/3)

Read more:
https://t.co/a0FKtFQH7Q

name: NPR
text:
GDP shrank at an annual rate of 32.9% in the second quarter — the sharpest economic contraction in modern American history.

The economic shock in April, May and June was more than 3 times as sharp as the previous record — 10% in 1958.
https://t.co/tfxF2oNQtF

name: NPR
text:
President Trump suggested delaying the November election on Twitter this morning.

His tweet came about 15 minutes after news of the worst quarterly performance of the American economy in modern history.
https://t.co/p31syGd9bQ

name: NPR
text:
A new poll finds more than half of voters under 35 say they don't have the resources or knowledge they need to vote by mail in November.

"The problem is we've never voted in a pandemic before, and some of these young people have never even voted before."
https://t.co/zJ4oaR5L2O

name: NPR
text:
Tropical Storm Isaias is hitting Puerto Rico with torrential rainfall and "life-threatening flash flooding," the NWS says.

The first tropical storm-force winds could arrive in Miami by late Friday.
https://t.co/98qQT1od6x
